patterns.name: Saju Jirugi
patterns.meaning: Four-direction Punch - basic punching practice in four directions
patterns.focus: Basic punching, stances, and directional awareness

movements.description: Assume parallel ready stance facing D
Left walking stance toward D while executing low block
Right walking stance toward D while executing middle punch

patterns.name: Saju Makgi
patterns.meaning: Four-direction Block - basic blocking practice in four directions
patterns.focus: Basic blocking techniques and directional movement

movements.description: Assume parallel ready stance facing D
Left walking stance toward D while executing rising block

patterns.name: Chon-Ji
patterns.meaning: Heaven and Earth - representing the beginning of the world
patterns.patternDescription: Cross-shaped pattern representing heaven and earth
patterns.focus: Introduction to pattern training, basic blocks and punches

movements.description: Assume parallel ready stance facing D
Turn left to B, left walking stance, left low block
Step forward to B, right walking stance, right middle punch
Turn right 180¬∞ to A, right walking stance, right low block
Step forward to A, left walking stance, left middle punch
Turn left 90¬∞ to D, left walking stance, left inner forearm middle block
Step forward to D, right walking stance, right middle punch
Turn right 180¬∞ to C, right walking stance, right inner forearm middle block
Step forward to C, left walking stance, left middle punch
Turn left 90¬∞ to B, left walking stance, left low block
Step forward to B, right walking stance, right middle punch
Step forward to B, left walking stance, left middle punch
Step forward to B, right walking stance, right middle punch with kihap
Turn left 180¬∞ to A, left walking stance, left low block
Step forward to A, right walking stance, right middle punch
Step forward to A, left walking stance, left middle punch
Step forward to A, right walking stance, right middle punch with kihap
Turn left 90¬∞ to D, left walking stance, left inner forearm middle block
Bring right foot to left foot, parallel ready stance facing D

patterns.name: Dan-Gun
patterns.meaning: Named after the holy Dan-Gun, legendary founder of Korea in 2333 BC
patterns.focus: Walking stance, middle section punches, and front snap kick

movements.description: Assume parallel ready stance facing D
Turn left to B, left walking stance, left middle block
Step forward to B, right walking stance, right high punch
Turn right 180¬∞ to A, right walking stance, right middle block
Step forward to A, left walking stance, left high punch
Turn left 90¬∞ to D, right L-stance, knife-hand guarding block
Step forward to D, left walking stance, left middle punch
Step forward to D, right walking stance, right middle punch
Turn right 270¬∞ to C, left L-stance, knife-hand guarding block
Step forward to C, right walking stance, right middle punch
Step forward to C, left walking stance, left middle punch
Turn left 90¬∞ to B, left walking stance, left middle block
Step forward to B, right walking stance, right high punch
Turn right 180¬∞ to A, right walking stance, right middle block
Step forward to A, left walking stance, left high punch
Turn left 90¬∞ to D, left walking stance, left middle block
Right front snap kick, landing in right walking stance, right middle punch
Left front snap kick, landing in left walking stance, left middle punch
Right front snap kick, landing in right walking stance, right middle punch with kihap
Turn left 270¬∞ to C, left walking stance, left middle block
Bring right foot to left foot, parallel ready stance facing D

patterns.name: Do-San
patterns.meaning: Pseudonym of the patriot Ahn Chang-Ho (1876-1938)
patterns.focus: Front stance, twin forearm block, and side piercing kick

patterns.name: Won-Hyo
patterns.meaning: The noted monk who introduced Buddhism to the Silla Dynasty in 686 AD
patterns.focus: L-stance, forearm guarding block, and side thrusting kick

patterns.name: Yul-Gok
patterns.meaning: Pseudonym of great philosopher and scholar Yi I (1536-1584)
patterns.focus: Sitting stance, upset punches, and knife-hand strikes

patterns.name: Joong-Gun
patterns.meaning: Named after patriot Ahn Joong-Gun who assassinated Hiro-Bumi Ito
patterns.patternDescription: Pattern representing 32 movements for his age at death
patterns.focus: Twisting stance, twin vertical punches, and back fist strikes

patterns.name: Toi-Gye
patterns.meaning: Pen name of the noted scholar Yi Hwang (16th century)
patterns.patternDescription: Scholar pattern representing his 37 years of development
patterns.focus: X-stance, circular blocks, and reverse knife-hand strikes

patterns.name: Hwa-Rang
patterns.meaning: Named after the Hwa-Rang youth group of the Silla Dynasty
patterns.focus: Low stance, elbow strikes, and knee strikes

patterns.name: Choong-Moo
patterns.meaning: Named after Admiral Yi Soon-Sin who invented the first armored battleship
patterns.patternDescription: Pattern ending with left hand attack representing his unfinished work
patterns.focus: Bending ready stance, upward kicks, and flying techniques

patterns.name: Kwang-Gae
patterns.meaning: Named after Kwang-Gae-Toh-Wang, 19th king of the Koguryo Dynasty
patterns.patternDescription: Pattern representing expansion and recovery of lost territories
patterns.focus: Wide stance, palm heel strikes, and pushing techniques

patterns.name: Po-Eun
patterns.meaning: Pseudonym of loyal subject Chong Mong-Chu (14th century)
patterns.patternDescription: Straight line representing his unerring loyalty to the king
patterns.focus: Fixed stance, side elbow thrust, and horizontal strikes

patterns.name: Ge-Baek
patterns.meaning: Named after Ge-Baek, a great general from the Baek Je Dynasty
patterns.patternDescription: Straight line representing severe and strict military discipline
patterns.focus: Close stance, slow motion techniques, and simultaneous blocks

patterns.name: Eui-Am
patterns.meaning: Pseudonym of Son Byong Hi, leader of Korean Independence Movement
patterns.focus: Shifted stance, U-shaped blocks, and circular techniques

patterns.name: Choong-Jang
patterns.meaning: Pseudonym of Kim Duk Ryang, a great general and poet
patterns.patternDescription: Pattern ending with left hand attack representing his tragic death
patterns.focus: Bent wrist strikes, pressing blocks, and crescent kicks

patterns.name: Juche
patterns.meaning: Philosophical idea that man is the master of everything
patterns.patternDescription: Mountain shape representing the Baekdu Mountain
patterns.focus: Overlapping kicks, jumping techniques, and combination attacks

patterns.name: Sam-Il
patterns.meaning: Historical date of Korean Independence Movement (March 1, 1919)
patterns.focus: Waving techniques, circular motions, and rhythmic patterns

patterns.name: Yoo-Sin
patterns.meaning: Named after General Kim Yoo Sin, unified three kingdoms of Korea
patterns.focus: Flexible stances, flowing movements, and continuous techniques

patterns.name: Choi-Yong
patterns.meaning: Named after General Choi Yong, premier and commander-in-chief
patterns.focus: Strong linear movements, powerful strikes, and stable stances

patterns.name: Yong-Gae
patterns.meaning: Named after famous general during Koguryo Dynasty
patterns.focus: Aggressive attacks, rapid combinations, and powerful kicks

patterns.name: Ul-Ji
patterns.meaning: Named after General Ul-Ji Moon Dok who defended Korea against Chinese
patterns.focus: Deceptive movements, tactical positioning, and counter-attacks

patterns.name: Moon-Moo
patterns.meaning: Named after 30th king of Silla Dynasty
patterns.patternDescription: Pattern representing his death and burial at sea
patterns.focus: Graceful movements, flowing transitions, and circular defense

patterns.name: So-San
patterns.meaning: Pseudonym of Choi Hyong Ung, great monk during Yi Dynasty
patterns.patternDescription: Mountain pattern representing his monastic life
patterns.focus: Endurance techniques, long combinations, and spiritual focus

patterns.name: Se-Jong
patterns.meaning: Named after greatest Korean king, inventor of Korean alphabet
patterns.focus: Precise movements, intellectual approach, and strategic positioning

patterns.name: Tong-Il
patterns.meaning: Represents the unification of Korea which has been divided since 1945
patterns.focus: Unified techniques, harmonious movements, and complete mastery
